elements.content: Aimed at the exploration of luminescent coordination polymer (LCP) systems for highly tunable luminophores, a new series of Cd­(II) LCPs, namely, [Cd2(tpt)2(CBA)2­(H2O)2]­·(PAH) (1), [Cd2(tpt)2­(CBA)2]­·(PAHs) (2–3) (tpt = 2,4,6-tri­(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine, H2CBA = 4-(carboxymethyl) benzoic acid, PAHs = polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, coronene for 1, perylene for 2, and triphenylene for 3), are successfully constructed based on the host–guest charge transfer (HGCT) mechanism. Through the PAHs directed coordination assembly of Cd­(II) ions, CBA2– and tpt ligands, compounds 1–3 exhibit the as-expected host–guest structures, in which PAHs-tpt donor–acceptor (D–A) systems are successfully achieved. Structural investigations of 1–3 show that the flexibility of the carboxylate ligand and the guest dependent donor–acceptor interaction affect their structures. In addition, 1–3 exhibit a guest-dependent wide emission range originating from the charge-transfer interactions of the D–A systems. What is more, the overlap between the acceptor tpt and donor guests may affect the emission of the compounds in addition to the ionization potential (IP) of the PAH guests, which can help the understanding and targeted modulation of the emission properties in related systems.
elements.clean_text: Aimed at the exploration of luminescent coordination polymer (LCP) systems for highly tunable luminophores, a new series of Cd(II) LCPs, namely, [Cd2(tpt)2(CBA)2(H2O)2]⋅(PAH) (1), [Cd2(tpt)2(CBA)2]⋅(PAHs) (2-3) (tpt = 2,4,6-tri(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine, H2CBA = 4-(carboxymethyl) benzoic acid, PAHs = polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, coronene for 1, perylene for 2, and triphenylene for 3), are successfully constructed based on the host-guest charge transfer (HGCT) mechanism. Through the PAHs directed coordination assembly of Cd(II) ions, CBA2- and tpt ligands, compounds 1-3 exhibit the as-expected host-guest structures, in which PAHs-tpt donor-acceptor (D-A) systems are successfully achieved. Structural investigations of 1-3 show that the flexibility of the carboxylate ligand and the guest dependent donor-acceptor interaction affect their structures. In addition, 1-3 exhibit a guest-dependent wide emission range originating from the charge-transfer interactions of the D-A systems. What is more, the overlap between the acceptor tpt and donor guests may affect the emission of the compounds in addition to the ionization potential (IP) of the PAH guests, which can help the understanding and targeted modulation of the emission properties in related systems.

elements.content: Three host−guest charge transfer coordination polymers are successfully constructed from the electron-deficient tpt and electron-rich PAH motifs as acceptor and donors, respectively. These compounds display guest-dependent structures, high thermal/chemical stability, and charge transfer based emissions. This method is promising for the modulation of potential luminophores’ structures and emission performance.
elements.clean_text: Three host-guest charge transfer coordination polymers are successfully constructed from the electron-deficient tpt and electron-rich PAH motifs as acceptor and donors, respectively. These compounds display guest-dependent structures, high thermal/chemical stability, and charge transfer based emissions. This method is promising for the modulation of potential luminophores' structures and emission performance.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

In recent years, luminescent coordination polymers (LCPs) have attracted much attention owing to their readily tailorable structures and modulatable emission properties, making them promising luminophores for the applications in sensing, anticounterfeiting, and organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). To date, much effort has been made for the targeted emission modulation of LCPs. Due to the metal center or ligand determined emission properties of most LCPs, the rational introduction of metal centers (mainly lanthanide ions) and utilization of well-designed organic linkers with special emissions have been well developed as effective modulation strategies. However, the limited species of emissive metal ions and the complicated design and synthesis of organic linkers make the flexible emission tuning of LCPs a challenging task. This challenge can be tackled with host–guest chemistry, promoting a brand new stage for the construction of LCPs. With this method, the emission targeted construction of the CPs can be achieved by introducing emissive guest molecules into the host frameworks. Taking the advantage of the highly ordered framework structures of the host CPs, the arrangement and distribution of guests in the frameworks can be regulated to prevent aggregation induced fluorescence self-quenching. Therefore, the resulting LCP can exhibit the emission of the host framework or the guest on the basis of host–guest energy transfer or a simple overlap of both under proper excitation.
elements.clean_text:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Crystalline Functional Materials in Honor of Professor Xin-Tao Wu

Introduction

In recent years, luminescent coordination polymers (LCPs) have attracted much attention owing to their readily tailorable structures and modulatable emission properties, making them promising luminophores for the applications in sensing, anticounterfeiting, and organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). To date, much effort has been made for the targeted emission modulation of LCPs. Due to the metal center or ligand determined emission properties of most LCPs, the rational introduction of metal centers (mainly lanthanide ions) and utilization of well-designed organic linkers with special emissions have been well developed as effective modulation strategies. However, the limited species of emissive metal ions and the complicated design and synthesis of organic linkers make the flexible emission tuning of LCPs a challenging task. This challenge can be tackled with host-guest chemistry, promoting a brand new stage for the construction of LCPs. With this method, the emission targeted construction of the CPs can be achieved by introducing emissive guest molecules into the host frameworks. Taking the advantage of the highly ordered framework structures of the host CPs, the arrangement and distribution of guests in the frameworks can be regulated to prevent aggregation induced fluorescence self-quenching. Therefore, the resulting LCP can exhibit the emission of the host framework or the guest on the basis of host-guest energy transfer or a simple overlap of both under proper excitation.

elements.content: Beyond the method mentioned above, the occurrence of host–guest charge transfer (HGCT), with the host and guest species in LCPs as acceptor (A) and donors (D) respectively, provides an even more flexible and predictable manner for the emission tuning. Since the emission based on HGCT is mainly attributed to the electron transition between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of D and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of A, the emission wavelength of LCPs can be well predicted and rationally modulated through the utilization of proper D and A components with specific orbital energy levels. However, though some studies have reported the emissions of cocrystals on the basis of charge transfer interactions, there are only a few reports on the construction and research of LCPs based on HGCT. Therefore, such investigation is still in its infancy, and more research and investigations are necessary for the illustration of the targeted construction and emission tuning principles of the LCPs.
elements.clean_text: Beyond the method mentioned above, the occurrence of host-guest charge transfer (HGCT), with the host and guest species in LCPs as acceptor (A) and donors (D) respectively, provides an even more flexible and predictable manner for the emission tuning. Since the emission based on HGCT is mainly attributed to the electron transition between the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of D and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of A, the emission wavelength of LCPs can be well predicted and rationally modulated through the utilization of proper D and A components with specific orbital energy levels. However, though some studies have reported the emissions of cocrystals on the basis of charge transfer interactions, there are only a few reports on the construction and research of LCPs based on HGCT. Therefore, such investigation is still in its infancy, and more research and investigations are necessary for the illustration of the targeted construction and emission tuning principles of the LCPs.

elements.content: On the basis of our previous work, we have made continuous efforts on the expansion and research of HGCT based LCPs with 2,4,6-tri­(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) as the acceptor component. By taking the advantages of triazine as a typical electron-deficient motif and the readily accessible planar backbone, tpt is an ideal acceptor building block for the construction of CT system. On the other hand, different auxiliary carboxylate ligands are introduced into the assembly system aiming at the structural diversity of host CPs. Also, as the donor component to accomplish the CT system, various electron-rich polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are also employed for emission tuning. Herein, we report the construction and emission properties of a series of Cd­(II) LCPs with 4-(carboxymethyl) benzoic acid (H2CBA) as the auxiliary ligand. A series of LCPs, namely, [Cd2(tpt)2­(CBA)2(H2O)2]­·(coronene) (1), [Cd2(tpt)2­(CBA)2]­·(perylene)­·2­(H2O) (2) and [Cd2(tpt)2­(CBA)2]­·(triphenylene)·2­(H2O) (3), were obtained with different PAHs as guests (). In contrast to the layered structures reported before, these compounds feature three-dimensional (3D) host–guest structures owing to the coordination conformation of CBA2– ligand and the guest-dependent D–A interaction. As expected, the emission properties of the compounds are found to be guest-dependent and highly tunable, while the HGCT based emission may also be affected by the overlap between the acceptor tpt and donor guests in addition to the ionization potential (IP) of the PAH guests, which can help the understanding and targeted modulation of the emission properties in related systems.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of our previous work, we have made continuous efforts on the expansion and research of HGCT based LCPs with 2,4,6-tri(pyridin-4-yl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) as the acceptor component. By taking the advantages of triazine as a typical electron-deficient motif and the readily accessible planar backbone, tpt is an ideal acceptor building block for the construction of CT system. On the other hand, different auxiliary carboxylate ligands are introduced into the assembly system aiming at the structural diversity of host CPs. Also, as the donor component to accomplish the CT system, various electron-rich polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are also employed for emission tuning. Herein, we report the construction and emission properties of a series of Cd(II) LCPs with 4-(carboxymethyl) benzoic acid (H2CBA) as the auxiliary ligand. A series of LCPs, namely, [Cd2(tpt)2(CBA)2(H2O)2]⋅(coronene) (1), [Cd2(tpt)2(CBA)2]⋅(perylene)⋅2(H2O) (2) and [Cd2(tpt)2(CBA)2]⋅(triphenylene)⋅2(H2O) (3), were obtained with different PAHs as guests (). In contrast to the layered structures reported before, these compounds feature three-dimensional (3D) host-guest structures owing to the coordination conformation of CBA2- ligand and the guest-dependent D-A interaction. As expected, the emission properties of the compounds are found to be guest-dependent and highly tunable, while the HGCT based emission may also be affected by the overlap between the acceptor tpt and donor guests in addition to the ionization potential (IP) of the PAH guests, which can help the understanding and targeted modulation of the emission properties in related systems.

elements.content:
Construction of Donor–Acceptor Systems Based on Host-Guest CPs with Electron-Rich PAH Guests and Electron-Deficient tpt for Effective HGCT Emissions<xref ref-type="fn" rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

The PAH guest molecules are shown in yellow for coronene, red for perylene, and green for triphenylene, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 1  Construction of Donor-Acceptor Systems Based on Host-Guest CPs with Electron-Rich PAH Guests and Electron-Deficient tpt for Effective HGCT Emissions      a The PAH guest molecules are shown in yellow for coronene, red for perylene, and green for triphenylene, respectively.

elements.content:
The PAH guest molecules are shown in yellow for coronene, red for perylene, and green for triphenylene, respectively.

Results and DiscussionConstruction and Crystal Structures of Compounds <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold>

As mentioned in the introduction, the H2CBA was introduced in this work to find the potentially new LCP systems. The H2CBA ligand features diverse conformations on the basis of the presence of flexible methylene linker between the carboxyl group and the benzene backbone. Compared with the 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (H2PDA) ligand with two methylene linkers used in our previous work, the flexibility of H2CBA is somewhat reduced. Then it is expected that distinct framework structures could be obtained with this ligand. In consideration of the successful construction method we reported before, the CPs’ crystals were obtained by the solvothermal method with coronene, perylene, and triphenylene introduced for one-step assembly. The PAHs-dependent colors of the samples suggest the successful incorporation of guests and the establishment of D–A systems. Then the samples were named as 1–3 depending on the PAHs used, and the structures of the compounds were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses.
elements.clean_text:
a The PAH guest molecules are shown in yellow for coronene, red for perylene, and green for triphenylene, respectively.  

Results and Discussion

Construction and Crystal Structures of Compounds 1-3 

As mentioned in the introduction, the H2CBA was introduced in this work to find the potentially new LCP systems. The H2CBA ligand features diverse conformations on the basis of the presence of flexible methylene linker between the carboxyl group and the benzene backbone. Compared with the 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (H2PDA) ligand with two methylene linkers used in our previous work, the flexibility of H2CBA is somewhat reduced. Then it is expected that distinct framework structures could be obtained with this ligand. In consideration of the successful construction method we reported before, the CPs' crystals were obtained by the solvothermal method with coronene, perylene, and triphenylene introduced for one-step assembly. The PAHs-dependent colors of the samples suggest the successful incorporation of guests and the establishment of D-A systems. Then the samples were named as 1-3 depending on the PAHs used, and the structures of the compounds were determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the Cc space group of the monoclinic system. The asymmetric unit contains two Cd­(II) ions, two CBA2– ligands, two tpt ligands, two coordinated water molecules, and one free coronene. The Cd­(II) centers reveal two kinds of coordination modes. One kind of Cd­(II) center is coordinated by five oxygen atoms from three CBA2– ligands with chelating and monobridging modes, and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two distinct tpt ligands, forming a distorted [N2O5] pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry. The other Cd­(II) center adopts octahedral coordination geometry by connecting with four oxygen atoms from two CBA2– ligands, two coordinated water molecules, and two nitrogen atoms from tpt ligands (a). The Cd–O bond lengths range from 2.216 to 2.609 Å, and the Cd–N bond lengths are 2.351–2.405 Å, which are in normal ranges. The CBA2– ligands also reveal two different kinds of coordination modes. For one kind, the two carboxyl groups adopt bidentate chelating mode to link two adjacent Cd­(II) ions, while for the other kind, the two carboxyl groups assume monobridging and bidentate bridging modes (b). On the basis of the connection between Cd­(II) ions and CBA2– ligands, double-chains are formed (d). For the tpt ligands, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms in one tpt ligand link two Cd­(II) ions from two different double chains (c), while one pyridyl group is left free. The connection between chains and tpt ligands generates an extended 3D framework (e). There are one-dimensional (1D) channels along the b axis in the framework, which are occupied by coronene molecules. The coronene molecules show a face-to face packing mode toward the tpt ligands with DAA modes (f), and the vertical distance between the center of triazine ring of tpt to the corresponding coronene molecule is about 3.324 Å. The relatively short distance indicates a strong interaction between tpt and coronene, which guarantees the formation of the D–A system.
elements.clean_text: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the Cc space group of the monoclinic system. The asymmetric unit contains two Cd(II) ions, two CBA2- ligands, two tpt ligands, two coordinated water molecules, and one free coronene. The Cd(II) centers reveal two kinds of coordination modes. One kind of Cd(II) center is coordinated by five oxygen atoms from three CBA2- ligands with chelating and monobridging modes, and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two distinct tpt ligands, forming a distorted [N2O5] pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry. The other Cd(II) center adopts octahedral coordination geometry by connecting with four oxygen atoms from two CBA2- ligands, two coordinated water molecules, and two nitrogen atoms from tpt ligands (a). The Cd-O bond lengths range from 2.216 to 2.609 Å, and the Cd-N bond lengths are 2.351-2.405 Å, which are in normal ranges. The CBA2- ligands also reveal two different kinds of coordination modes. For one kind, the two carboxyl groups adopt bidentate chelating mode to link two adjacent Cd(II) ions, while for the other kind, the two carboxyl groups assume monobridging and bidentate bridging modes (b). On the basis of the connection between Cd(II) ions and CBA2- ligands, double-chains are formed (d). For the tpt ligands, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms in one tpt ligand link two Cd(II) ions from two different double chains (c), while one pyridyl group is left free. The connection between chains and tpt ligands generates an extended 3D framework (e). There are one-dimensional (1D) channels along the b axis in the framework, which are occupied by coronene molecules. The coronene molecules show a face-to face packing mode toward the tpt ligands with DAA modes (f), and the vertical distance between the center of triazine ring of tpt to the corresponding coronene molecule is about 3.324 Å. The relatively short distance indicates a strong interaction between tpt and coronene, which guarantees the formation of the D-A system.

elements.content: Crystal structure of compound 1. (a) Coordination environment of Cd­(II) ions (symmetric codes: A (0.5 + x, −0.5 + y, z), B (x, −1 + y, z), C (0.5 + x, 0.5 – y, −0.5 + z), D (x, −y, 0.5 + z)). The free coronene guest is highlighted in yellow. (b) Coordination modes of CBA2– ligands. (c) Coordination mode of tpt ligand. (d) The one-dimensional double-chain formed by carboxyl groups in CBA2– ligands and Cd­(II) ions. (e) The 3D framework based on tpt ligands connecting with double chains. (f) The state of coronene guests in the host framework. H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of compound 1. (a) Coordination environment of Cd(II) ions (symmetric codes: A (0.5 + x, -0.5 + y, z), B (x, -1 + y, z), C (0.5 + x, 0.5 - y, -0.5 + z), D (x, -y, 0.5 + z)). The free coronene guest is highlighted in yellow. (b) Coordination modes of CBA2- ligands. (c) Coordination mode of tpt ligand. (d) The one-dimensional double-chain formed by carboxyl groups in CBA2- ligands and Cd(II) ions. (e) The 3D framework based on tpt ligands connecting with double chains. (f) The state of coronene guests in the host framework. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: From the crystal structure investigations, it was found that the structures of compounds 2 and 3 are quite similar but different from that of 1. Therefore, only the structural description of 2 is demonstrated in detail as follows. Compound 2 crystallizes in the P21/c space group of the monoclinic system, and the asymmetric unit contains two Cd­(II) ions, two CBA2– ligands, two tpt ligands, and one free perylene. Both Cd­(II) ions adopt distorted [N2O4] octahedral geometry by coordinating with four carboxyl oxygen atoms from three CBA2– ligands and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two tpt moieties (a). The Cd–O bond lengths range from 2.258 to 2.418 Å, and Cd–N bond lengths range from 2.309 to 2.316 Å, which are similar to those reported in the literature. The two carboxyl groups in CBA2– ligands adopt bidentate chelating and bidentate bridging modes to connect three Cd­(II) ions to form 2D layers (b,d), and these 2D layers are further linked by tpt to generate a 3D framework owning 1D channels (c,e). As expected, perylene molecules are located in the 1D channels as guests through their π–π interactions with tpt molecules, which also exhibit DAA packing modes (f). The distance between the tpt backbone and perylene is about 3.467 Å, which is just in the range of the π–π distance. Compound 3 has a similar structure with that of 2 except that the 1D channels are occupied by triphenylene instead of perylene, and the distance between tpt and triphenylene is about 3.475 Å ().
elements.clean_text: From the crystal structure investigations, it was found that the structures of compounds 2 and 3 are quite similar but different from that of 1. Therefore, only the structural description of 2 is demonstrated in detail as follows. Compound 2 crystallizes in the P21/c space group of the monoclinic system, and the asymmetric unit contains two Cd(II) ions, two CBA2- ligands, two tpt ligands, and one free perylene. Both Cd(II) ions adopt distorted [N2O4] octahedral geometry by coordinating with four carboxyl oxygen atoms from three CBA2- ligands and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from two tpt moieties (a). The Cd-O bond lengths range from 2.258 to 2.418 Å, and Cd-N bond lengths range from 2.309 to 2.316 Å, which are similar to those reported in the literature. The two carboxyl groups in CBA2- ligands adopt bidentate chelating and bidentate bridging modes to connect three Cd(II) ions to form 2D layers (b,d), and these 2D layers are further linked by tpt to generate a 3D framework owning 1D channels (c,e). As expected, perylene molecules are located in the 1D channels as guests through their π-π interactions with tpt molecules, which also exhibit DAA packing modes (f). The distance between the tpt backbone and perylene is about 3.467 Å, which is just in the range of the π-π distance. Compound 3 has a similar structure with that of 2 except that the 1D channels are occupied by triphenylene instead of perylene, and the distance between tpt and triphenylene is about 3.475 Å ().

elements.content: Crystal structure of compound 2: (a) Coordination environment of Cd­(II) ions (symmetric codes: A (1 – x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z), B (1 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z), C (1 + x, y, z), D (2 – x, 1 – y, 1 – z), E (2 −x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 – z)). The free perylene guest is highlighted in red. (b) Coordination mode of the CBA2– ligand. (c) Coordination mode of the tpt ligand. (d) Two-dimensional layer formed by CBA2– ligands and Cd­(II) ions. (e) The 3D framework connected by two-dimensional layers and tpt ligands. (f) The state of perylene guest molecules in the host framework. The uncoordinated solvent molecules and H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of compound 2: (a) Coordination environment of Cd(II) ions (symmetric codes: A (1 - x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z), B (1 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z), C (1 + x, y, z), D (2 - x, 1 - y, 1 - z), E (2 -x, 0.5 + y, 0.5 - z)). The free perylene guest is highlighted in red. (b) Coordination mode of the CBA2- ligand. (c) Coordination mode of the tpt ligand. (d) Two-dimensional layer formed by CBA2- ligands and Cd(II) ions. (e) The 3D framework connected by two-dimensional layers and tpt ligands. (f) The state of perylene guest molecules in the host framework. The uncoordinated solvent molecules and H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Crystal structure of compound 3: (a) Coordination environment of Cd­(II) ions (symmetric codes: A (−x, 1 – y, 1 – z), B (−x, −0.5 + y, 1.5 – z), C (−1 + x, y, z), D (1 – x, −0.5 + y, 1.5 – z)). The free triphenylene guest is highlighted in green. (b) Coordination mode of CBA2– ligand. (c) Coordination mode of tpt ligand. (d) Two-dimensional plane formed by CBA2– ligands and Cd­(II) ions. (e) The 3D framework formed by the connection of two-dimensional layers and tpt ligands. (f) The state of triphenylene guest in the host framework. The uncoordinated solvent molecules and H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of compound 3: (a) Coordination environment of Cd(II) ions (symmetric codes: A (-x, 1 - y, 1 - z), B (-x, -0.5 + y, 1.5 - z), C (-1 + x, y, z), D (1 - x, -0.5 + y, 1.5 - z)). The free triphenylene guest is highlighted in green. (b) Coordination mode of CBA2- ligand. (c) Coordination mode of tpt ligand. (d) Two-dimensional plane formed by CBA2- ligands and Cd(II) ions. (e) The 3D framework formed by the connection of two-dimensional layers and tpt ligands. (f) The state of triphenylene guest in the host framework. The uncoordinated solvent molecules and H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: By comparing the structures of 1 with that of 2 and 3, it is obvious that the structure of host framework is guest-dependent, which should be affected by the distinct guest–framework interactions as well as the dimensions of PAH guests. Considering the nature of the interaction between the host framework and the guest and the aromatic nature of the guests, the intensity of the interaction should be in proportion to the dimensions of the guest molecules. Therefore, the dimensions of guest molecules indeed have influence on the construction of structures. In detail, as the dimension of coronene molecules in 1 is larger than that of perylene in 2 and triphenylene in 3, it is obvious that the distance between tpt and the guest in 1 (3.324 Å) is shorter than those in 2 (3.467 Å) and 3 (3.475 Å). This result also indicates stronger host–guest π–π interactions in 1 than that in 2 and 3. Concomitantly, one kind of CBA2– ligands in 1 adopts a bidentate chelating mode to adapt the relatively shorter distance, while those in 2 and 3 all take bidentate chelating and bidentate bridging modes (b, b, and b). All these different structure features reveal that PAH guest molecules play a significant role in the assembly of host–guest coordination polymers. On the other hand, by comparing with our previous work in which four coordination polymers reveal isomorphic structures in spite of different PAH guest molecules, the structures reported here suggest that flexibility of the ligand could affect the structure of the final product. The more flexible PDA2– results in 2D layer structures with its tortile conformation, while the CBA2– with increased rigidity gives 3D frameworks. All the facts mentioned above demonstrate that the structural diversity of related systems could be expected with different auxiliary ligands and PAH guests. This could also be a potential method for structural modulation. On the other hand, the contents of guests in the host frameworks of bulk samples were determined by elemental analysis. The well fitted experimental results and theoretical values from the crystallographic data (Supporting Information) suggest a full loading of all the pore voids of 1–3 under the synthesis condition. The effective guest loading in the pore voids of 1–3 should be attributed to the relatively strong interaction between the tpt ligand and guests that facilitate their stacking assembly.
elements.clean_text: By comparing the structures of 1 with that of 2 and 3, it is obvious that the structure of host framework is guest-dependent, which should be affected by the distinct guest-framework interactions as well as the dimensions of PAH guests. Considering the nature of the interaction between the host framework and the guest and the aromatic nature of the guests, the intensity of the interaction should be in proportion to the dimensions of the guest molecules. Therefore, the dimensions of guest molecules indeed have influence on the construction of structures. In detail, as the dimension of coronene molecules in 1 is larger than that of perylene in 2 and triphenylene in 3, it is obvious that the distance between tpt and the guest in 1 (3.324 Å) is shorter than those in 2 (3.467 Å) and 3 (3.475 Å). This result also indicates stronger host-guest π-π interactions in 1 than that in 2 and 3. Concomitantly, one kind of CBA2- ligands in 1 adopts a bidentate chelating mode to adapt the relatively shorter distance, while those in 2 and 3 all take bidentate chelating and bidentate bridging modes (b, b, and b). All these different structure features reveal that PAH guest molecules play a significant role in the assembly of host-guest coordination polymers. On the other hand, by comparing with our previous work in which four coordination polymers reveal isomorphic structures in spite of different PAH guest molecules, the structures reported here suggest that flexibility of the ligand could affect the structure of the final product. The more flexible PDA2- results in 2D layer structures with its tortile conformation, while the CBA2- with increased rigidity gives 3D frameworks. All the facts mentioned above demonstrate that the structural diversity of related systems could be expected with different auxiliary ligands and PAH guests. This could also be a potential method for structural modulation. On the other hand, the contents of guests in the host frameworks of bulk samples were determined by elemental analysis. The well fitted experimental results and theoretical values from the crystallographic data (Supporting Information) suggest a full loading of all the pore voids of 1-3 under the synthesis condition. The effective guest loading in the pore voids of 1-3 should be attributed to the relatively strong interaction between the tpt ligand and guests that facilitate their stacking assembly.

elements.content: In addition to the structure characterization of the compounds, the phase purities of the bulk samples were characterized subsequently by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The experimental patterns match well with the simulated ones, which manifests the high crystallinity and good phase purities of the samples (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Phase Purity and Stability Analyses

In addition to the structure characterization of the compounds, the phase purities of the bulk samples were characterized subsequently by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The experimental patterns match well with the simulated ones, which manifests the high crystallinity and good phase purities of the samples (Figure S1).

elements.content: Meanwhile, the chemical stability of the samples were evaluated by their resistance to aqua and organic solvents. The samples of 1, 2, and 3 were soaked in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), acetonitrile (CH3CN), ethanol (C2H5OH), methanol (CH3OH), and water (H2O) for 24 h, and then PXRD analyses were performed to verify their structures. The almost unchanged patterns confirm that the compounds are impervious to common organic solvents and water (Figure S1). The high chemical stability can be attributed to the strong π–π packing modes between the host frameworks and guest PAH molecules, which stabilized the frameworks effectively.
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, the chemical stability of the samples were evaluated by their resistance to aqua and organic solvents. The samples of 1, 2, and 3 were soaked in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), acetonitrile (CH3CN), ethanol (C2H5OH), methanol (CH3OH), and water (H2O) for 24 h, and then PXRD analyses were performed to verify their structures. The almost unchanged patterns confirm that the compounds are impervious to common organic solvents and water (Figure S1). The high chemical stability can be attributed to the strong π-π packing modes between the host frameworks and guest PAH molecules, which stabilized the frameworks effectively.

elements.content: In addition to the phase purity and chemical stability characterizations, the thermal stability investigations of 1–3 were represented by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S2). The profile of 1 presents no obvious loss before 350 °C, which is consistent with the absence of free solvent molecules, while the curve of 2 exhibits a slight loss (2.1%) before 400 °C in accordance with free water molecules (calculated 2.4%). The profile of 3 reveals a continuous loss of weight about 8.6% before 280 °C, which may correspond to the removal of free water molecules and one carboxyl group in CBA2– ligand (calculated 8.4%) in the framework. It is worthy of note that the PAHs in 1–3 are apt to sublimate at high temperature in a free state, while they are retained well in the host frameworks before the decomposition of the compounds. This should be attributed to the strong π–π interactions between the electron-rich PAHs and electron-deficient tpt ligands in the confined pore structures of the host frameworks.
elements.clean_text: In addition to the phase purity and chemical stability characterizations, the thermal stability investigations of 1-3 were represented by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S2). The profile of 1 presents no obvious loss before 350 °C, which is consistent with the absence of free solvent molecules, while the curve of 2 exhibits a slight loss (2.1%) before 400 °C in accordance with free water molecules (calculated 2.4%). The profile of 3 reveals a continuous loss of weight about 8.6% before 280 °C, which may correspond to the removal of free water molecules and one carboxyl group in CBA2- ligand (calculated 8.4%) in the framework. It is worthy of note that the PAHs in 1-3 are apt to sublimate at high temperature in a free state, while they are retained well in the host frameworks before the decomposition of the compounds. This should be attributed to the strong π-π interactions between the electron-rich PAHs and electron-deficient tpt ligands in the confined pore structures of the host frameworks.

elements.content: The successful introduction of electron-rich PAH guests into the electron-deficient host frameworks is prone to form effective charge-transfer systems, which makes the obtained compounds 1–3 favorable LCPs. Therefore, their photophysical properties were investigated systematically to explore their potential applications as luminophores.
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties

The successful introduction of electron-rich PAH guests into the electron-deficient host frameworks is prone to form effective charge-transfer systems, which makes the obtained compounds 1-3 favorable LCPs. Therefore, their photophysical properties were investigated systematically to explore their potential applications as luminophores.

elements.content: The formation of charge-transfer systems in the compounds could be preliminarily confirmed by their guest-dependent colors (a), which are the characteristics of donor–acceptor compounds. For further confirmation, the UV–vis absorption spectra of 1–3 were tested (Figure S3). All the three compounds present distinct broad absorption bands in the visible light region (>400 nm), which are consistent with their visible colors. In addition, these absorption bands are quite different from their corresponding guest molecules and the tpt ligand. Hence, the new absorption bands indicate the presence of HGCT interactions between the electron-rich PAH guests and electron-deficient tpt building blocks in the host frameworks.
elements.clean_text: The formation of charge-transfer systems in the compounds could be preliminarily confirmed by their guest-dependent colors (a), which are the characteristics of donor-acceptor compounds. For further confirmation, the UV-vis absorption spectra of 1-3 were tested (Figure S3). All the three compounds present distinct broad absorption bands in the visible light region (>400 nm), which are consistent with their visible colors. In addition, these absorption bands are quite different from their corresponding guest molecules and the tpt ligand. Hence, the new absorption bands indicate the presence of HGCT interactions between the electron-rich PAH guests and electron-deficient tpt building blocks in the host frameworks.

elements.content: (a) The daylight images (middle) and fluorescent images (bottom) (λex = 330–380 nm) of 1–3. (b) The normalized emission spectra of 1–3. (c) The CIE chromaticity diagram for 1–3 according to their relevant fluorescent data.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) The daylight images (middle) and fluorescent images (bottom) (λex = 330-380 nm) of 1-3. (b) The normalized emission spectra of 1-3. (c) The CIE chromaticity diagram for 1-3 according to their relevant fluorescent data.

elements.content: Upon the determination of HGCT interactions in 1–3, their photoluminescent emissions were further investigated (b and S4). Compared with the emission spectra of the corresponding guests and tpt ligand, 1–3 exhibit different single broad emission bands, which is the characteristic of charge-transfer based emissions. In detail, when excited at 400 nm, the emission maxima of 1–3 are found at 595, 682, and 530 nm, respectively. According to the corresponding coordinates in the chromaticity diagram (CIE), these emissions cover a wide range from yellow-green to red (c and ), in spite of the similarity of the structures of the compounds. The distinct emissions of the compounds suggest that the photoluminescent performance could be modulated widely by introducing distinct PAH guests.
elements.clean_text: Upon the determination of HGCT interactions in 1-3, their photoluminescent emissions were further investigated (b and S4). Compared with the emission spectra of the corresponding guests and tpt ligand, 1-3 exhibit different single broad emission bands, which is the characteristic of charge-transfer based emissions. In detail, when excited at 400 nm, the emission maxima of 1-3 are found at 595, 682, and 530 nm, respectively. According to the corresponding coordinates in the chromaticity diagram (CIE), these emissions cover a wide range from yellow-green to red (c and ), in spite of the similarity of the structures of the compounds. The distinct emissions of the compounds suggest that the photoluminescent performance could be modulated widely by introducing distinct PAH guests.

elements.content:
Summary of Solid-State Luminescent Data for <bold>1</bold>–<bold>3</bold> compound λex (nm) λem‑max (nm) CIE guest IP (eV) Φfl (%) average τ (ns) 1 400 595 (0.51, 0.48) 7.29 2.62 17.54 2 400 682 (0.66, 0.33) 6.97 <1 4.24 3 400 530 (0.35, 0.52) 7.88 20.49 21.41

Ionization potential data obtained from ref .

Subsequently, the relationship between the ionization potential (IP) of the guest molecules and the emission maximum wavelengths of 1–3 was explored ( and ) for better understanding of the emission modulation principles. In our previous research, a good linear relationship between the IP of the guests and the emission maxima was observed based on their CT based emission mechanism, which could facilitate the targeted emission modulation of the system. In contrast, although the emission maximum decreases along with the increasing guests’ IP in this work, the linear fitting results in an adj. r-square value of 93.52%. In consideration of the unambiguous emission mechanism based on the components and structures of the compounds, this unexpected result indicates new factors that affect their emission properties. First, a careful analysis of the structures about the subtle differences of the tpt conformations as an adaption to the coordination assembly was carried out. As shown in Figure S5, the tpt ligands reveal distinct conformations in three compounds with different torsion angles between the central trizine ring and the pyridine rings attached. For 1, the tpt ligands show two nearly complanate conformations with maximum torsion angles of 6.2° and 6.4° (Figure S5a,b). For 2, the minimum/maximum torsion angles of the two types of tpt ligands are 4.9/7.3° and 5.4/24.1 (27.9)°, respectively (Figure S5c,d). The minimum/maximum torsion angles in 3 reach 3.6/20.1° and 3.7/20.9°, respectively (Figure S5e,f). Since the CT based emissions of the compounds mainly originate from the electron transfer between the HOMO of guest (refer to the IP) and the LUMO of tpt, the different LUMO energy levels of tpt owing to their different conformations may affect the energy gap that determines the emission wavelength of the compounds. In consideration of this, theoretical calculation about the LUMO and HOMO energy levels of the tpt ligands was executed, and the result reveals that the tpt ligands with different torsion angles show almost negligible influence on their LUMO energy level, which indicates this is not the main factor (Figure S5). When the IP values were replaced by a corrected energy gap according to IPs-ELUMO (tpt), the adj. r-square of the linear fitting is 95.92% (Figure S6), which is negligible compared with before.
elements.clean_text: Subsequently, the relationship between the ionization potential (IP) of the guest molecules and the emission maximum wavelengths of 1-3 was explored ( and ) for better understanding of the emission modulation principles. In our previous research, a good linear relationship between the IP of the guests and the emission maxima was observed based on their CT based emission mechanism, which could facilitate the targeted emission modulation of the system. In contrast, although the emission maximum decreases along with the increasing guests' IP in this work, the linear fitting results in an adj. r-square value of 93.52%. In consideration of the unambiguous emission mechanism based on the components and structures of the compounds, this unexpected result indicates new factors that affect their emission properties. First, a careful analysis of the structures about the subtle differences of the tpt conformations as an adaption to the coordination assembly was carried out. As shown in Figure S5, the tpt ligands reveal distinct conformations in three compounds with different torsion angles between the central trizine ring and the pyridine rings attached. For 1, the tpt ligands show two nearly complanate conformations with maximum torsion angles of 6.2° and 6.4° (Figure S5a,b). For 2, the minimum/maximum torsion angles of the two types of tpt ligands are 4.9/7.3° and 5.4/24.1 (27.9)°, respectively (Figure S5c,d). The minimum/maximum torsion angles in 3 reach 3.6/20.1° and 3.7/20.9°, respectively (Figure S5e,f). Since the CT based emissions of the compounds mainly originate from the electron transfer between the HOMO of guest (refer to the IP) and the LUMO of tpt, the different LUMO energy levels of tpt owing to their different conformations may affect the energy gap that determines the emission wavelength of the compounds. In consideration of this, theoretical calculation about the LUMO and HOMO energy levels of the tpt ligands was executed, and the result reveals that the tpt ligands with different torsion angles show almost negligible influence on their LUMO energy level, which indicates this is not the main factor (Figure S5). When the IP values were replaced by a corrected energy gap according to IPs-ELUMO (tpt), the adj. r-square of the linear fitting is 95.92% (Figure S6), which is negligible compared with before.

elements.content: Relationship between the emission maxima of 1–3 and the ionization potential (IP) values of their corresponding guests.
elements.clean_text: 5  Relationship between the emission maxima of 1-3 and the ionization potential (IP) values of their corresponding guests.

elements.content: The results mentioned above indicate that there might be other factors that affect the emission properties. A more detailed analysis of the structures of the compounds show that it might be the overlap between the D and A components. As shown in , though the guest molecules are encapsulated in the host framework through the D–A interaction, the relative position between the tpt and PAHs are distinct owing to the relatively weak confinement effect of the channel pore space. This is different from our previous work, in which guests with similar backbone dimensions are confined in fixed cages and thus reveals a well-fitted linear correlation. It has been reported that the overlap of π systems will result in the red shift of emission originated from considerable excited state delocalization. Therefore, the more effective overlap of the tpt and guest molecules should result in more effective charge-transfer between them and the corresponding red-shifted emissions. Overall, these results suggest that the modulation of overlap between guests and ligand should also be considered for the rational emission tuning in HGCT systems.
elements.clean_text: The results mentioned above indicate that there might be other factors that affect the emission properties. A more detailed analysis of the structures of the compounds show that it might be the overlap between the D and A components. As shown in , though the guest molecules are encapsulated in the host framework through the D-A interaction, the relative position between the tpt and PAHs are distinct owing to the relatively weak confinement effect of the channel pore space. This is different from our previous work, in which guests with similar backbone dimensions are confined in fixed cages and thus reveals a well-fitted linear correlation. It has been reported that the overlap of π systems will result in the red shift of emission originated from considerable excited state delocalization. Therefore, the more effective overlap of the tpt and guest molecules should result in more effective charge-transfer between them and the corresponding red-shifted emissions. Overall, these results suggest that the modulation of overlap between guests and ligand should also be considered for the rational emission tuning in HGCT systems.

elements.content: Relative position and overlap between the tpt ligands and corresponding guest molecules in compound 1 (a, b), compound 2 (c, d), and compound 3 (e, f), respectively.
elements.clean_text: 6  Relative position and overlap between the tpt ligands and corresponding guest molecules in compound 1 (a, b), compound 2 (c, d), and compound 3 (e, f), respectively.

elements.content: In addition, the absolute quantum yields (Φ) of the compounds were further determined by the integration sphere method. The Φ values are 2.62% for 1, less than 1% for 2 and 20.49% for 3, respectively (). The Φ values reveal distinct increasing trend along with the increasing IP values of the guests. This could be rationalized by the distinct electron-donating capacities of the guest PAHs reflected by their IP. In detail, the stronger electron-donating capacities of perylene (IP = 6.97 eV) and coronene (IP = 7.29 eV) benefit the formation of radical ion pairs in the excited state, which would quench the CT based emissions of 1 and 2 accordingly. While the relatively modest electron-donating capacity of triphenylene (IP = 7.88 eV) could promote the formation of exciplex state, which leads to the relatively higher quantum yield of 3. Fluorescent times (τ) values were also detected ( and Figure S7), which displays an increasing trend along with the increase of IP of the guests. This may also be attributed to the deactivation of different emission species.
elements.clean_text: In addition, the absolute quantum yields (Φ) of the compounds were further determined by the integration sphere method. The Φ values are 2.62% for 1, less than 1% for 2 and 20.49% for 3, respectively (). The Φ values reveal distinct increasing trend along with the increasing IP values of the guests. This could be rationalized by the distinct electron-donating capacities of the guest PAHs reflected by their IP. In detail, the stronger electron-donating capacities of perylene (IP = 6.97 eV) and coronene (IP = 7.29 eV) benefit the formation of radical ion pairs in the excited state, which would quench the CT based emissions of 1 and 2 accordingly. While the relatively modest electron-donating capacity of triphenylene (IP = 7.88 eV) could promote the formation of exciplex state, which leads to the relatively higher quantum yield of 3. Fluorescent times (τ) values were also detected ( and Figure S7), which displays an increasing trend along with the increase of IP of the guests. This may also be attributed to the deactivation of different emission species.

elements.content: In summary, three new Cd­(II) LCPs were successfully constructed based on HGCT mechanism. The D–A systems can be achieved through the coordination regulated assembly of host–guest structures with electron-deficient tpt and electron-rich PAH moieties as acceptor and donors, respectively. The resulting coordination polymers exhibit guest-dependent structures and good thermal/chemical stability, which indicates the importance of PAH guest species in the assembly process and π–π stacking interactions with tpt moiety. The emissions of the LCPs can be tuned in a wide range based on their guest-dependent emission character. What is more, the HGCT based emission may also be affected by the overlap between the acceptor tpt and donor guests, which could help the understanding and targeted modulation of emission properties in related systems. All of these features demonstrate that the construction of LCPs based on HGCT mechanism is a promising method for their structural and emissive modulation aiming at luminophores applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, three new Cd(II) LCPs were successfully constructed based on HGCT mechanism. The D-A systems can be achieved through the coordination regulated assembly of host-guest structures with electron-deficient tpt and electron-rich PAH moieties as acceptor and donors, respectively. The resulting coordination polymers exhibit guest-dependent structures and good thermal/chemical stability, which indicates the importance of PAH guest species in the assembly process and π-π stacking interactions with tpt moiety. The emissions of the LCPs can be tuned in a wide range based on their guest-dependent emission character. What is more, the HGCT based emission may also be affected by the overlap between the acceptor tpt and donor guests, which could help the understanding and targeted modulation of emission properties in related systems. All of these features demonstrate that the construction of LCPs based on HGCT mechanism is a promising method for their structural and emissive modulation aiming at luminophores applications.

cln_elements.content:
In addition to the phase purity and chemical stability characterizations, the thermal stability investigations of 1–3 were represented by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S2). The profile of 1 presents no obvious loss before 350 °C, which is consistent with the absence of free solvent molecules, while the curve of 2 exhibits a slight loss (2.1%) before 400 °C in accordance with free water molecules (calculated 2.4%). The profile of 3 reveals a continuous loss of weight about 8.6% before 280 °C, which may correspond to the removal of free water molecules and one carboxyl group in CBA2– ligand (calculated 8.4%) in the framework. It is worthy of note that the PAHs in 1–3 are apt to sublimate at high temperature in a free state, while they are retained well in the host frameworks before the decomposition of the compounds. This should be attributed to the strong π–π interactions between the electron-rich PAHs and electron-deficient tpt ligands in the confined pore structures of the host frameworks.

Upon the determination of HGCT interactions in 1–3, their photoluminescent emissions were further investigated (b and S4). Compared with the emission spectra of the corresponding guests and tpt ligand, 1–3 exhibit different single broad emission bands, which is the characteristic of charge-transfer based emissions. In detail, when excited at 400 nm, the emission maxima of 1–3 are found at 595, 682, and 530 nm, respectively. According to the corresponding coordinates in the chromaticity diagram (CIE), these emissions cover a wide range from yellow-green to red (c and ), in spite of the similarity of the structures of the compounds. The distinct emissions of the compounds suggest that the photoluminescent performance could be modulated widely by introducing distinct PAH guests.

The free coronene guest is highlighted in yellow. (b) Coordination modes of CBA2– ligands. (c) Coordination mode of tpt ligand. (d) The one-dimensional double-chain formed by carboxyl groups in CBA2– ligands and Cd­(II) ions. (e) The 3D framework based on tpt ligands connecting with double chains. (f) The state of coronene guests in the host framework. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

metadata.title:
Structure and Emission
Modulation of a Series of Cd(II)
Luminescent Coordination Polymers through Guest Dependent Donor–Acceptor
Interaction
